data.title: Largest airport in Europe by passenger volume
data.meta_description: Which is the largest airport in Europe and whether an American airport features in the top 10. Latest news and rankings for interested travelers.
data.text:
Nowadays, travelers don’t just go on vacation by car – especially not if they are going beyond national borders. That is why airports have become an integral part of the travel and economic infrastructure. Especially in Europe, a hub of global routes, airports are evidence of the enormous mobility. Find out which are the top 10 largest airports in Europe by passenger numbers.

Largest airports in Europe by passengers in 2023

What are the 10 largest airports in Europe by passenger numbers? Let’s take a closer look at the top 10 biggest and largest airports in Europe.

1st place: London Heathrow Airport (LHR), United Kingdom

With around 79.1 million passengers in 2023, London Heathrow Airport once again confirms its status as Europe’s leading aviation hub. As one of the best-connected airports, Heathrow offers direct flights to almost 220 destinations in around 85 countries.

2nd place: Istanbul Airport (IST), Turkey

Istanbul Airport (IST) recorded around 76.03 million travelers in 2023, making it the second largest airport in Europe. Thanks to its geographical location between Europe and Asia, IST builds a bridge between the two continents.

3rd place: Paris Charles de Gaulle Airport (CDG), France

Paris Airport, with 67.42 million travelers in 2023, ranks 3rd in the ranking and is the largest airport in France.

Its namesake was a general and statesman who became known as the leader of Free France during the Second World War and later served as President of the Fifth Republic of France.

4th place: Amsterdam Schiphol Airport (AMS), Netherlands

Our neighboring country is home to Amsterdam Schiphol Airport, which attracted a whopping 61.89 million travelers in 2023. The oldest international flight connection has been operating here since 1920: Amsterdam – Hamburg. Travelers can now reach 288 destinations worldwide from Amsterdam.

5th place: Adolfo Suárez Madrid-Barajas Airport (MAD), Spain

With a passenger volume of 60.18 million in 2023, Adolfo Suárez Madrid-Barajas Airport underlines its role as Spain’s most important gateway to the world. This airport was named after the Spanish politician who played a key role as Spain’s first democratically elected prime minister.

6th place: Frankfurt am Main Airport (FRA), Germany

59.36 million travelers passed through the airport in Frankfurt am Main in 2023. As one of the busiest airports in Europe, Frankfurt offers direct flights to over 290 destinations in 92 countries.

7th place: Barcelona-El Prat Airport (BCN), Spain

Barcelona-El Prat Airport recorded a passenger volume of 49.88 million in 2023, confirming its position as the second largest airport in Spain and an important hub in the Mediterranean region.

8th place: London Gatwick Airport (LGW), United Kingdom

In 2023, 40.90 million passengers traveled through London Gatwick Airport. As London’s second largest airport, Gatwick offers direct flights to 195 destinations in 61 countries.

9th place: Leonardo da Vinci Airport Rome-Fiumicino (FCO), Italy

Leonardo da Vinci Rome-Fiumicino Airport recorded 40.49 million travelers in 2023, confirming its position as Italy’s largest airport. FCO offers direct connections to 240 destinations in 76 countries.

10th place: Istanbul-Sabiha Gökçen Airport (SAW), Turkey

With a total of 37.1 million passengers in 2023, Istanbul-Sabiha Gökçen Airport is an essential part of Turkey’s air transportation system and serves as an important hub for flights within Europe and Asia.
